Award.AbstractNarration:
This geoinformatics award will support the continued development of the alphaMELTS software package to provide a flexible, powerful, easy-to-use interface and related tools. The three-year project will employ an early-career, female scientist to create the next software generation, to interact with users to implement requested features and support their modeling efforts, to test and demonstrate the new features, to optimize the package for use in teaching, and to publicize its educational features to encourage wide adoption. All software developed by this project will be released free of charge for use by the scientific community.

Projects supported by this new software package include models and algorithms for computational thermodynamics in petrology, geochemistry, and geodynamics. It enables earth scientists to execute forward models of complex petrogenetic scenarios with internal thermodynamic consistency and integrated volatile and trace element calculations. The project will explore the opening of an alphaMELTS XSEDE gateway to enable access to national high-performance computing resources and integration of computational thermodynamics into geodynamic codes on an unprecedented scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MELTS family of models can be used to study coexisting magma and minerals in igneous systems. MELTS has been the work of Mark Ghiorso (OFM Research) and co-workers, for more than twenty years. During that time, PI Asimow and colleagues at Caltech have added numerous features, many of them targeting the study of magma formation at mid-ocean ridges, mantle hotspots (such as Hawai’i), and “damp spots” (such as the Azores). alphaMELTS 2, the subject of this NSF award, was a complete rewrite of the Caltech software. It can now be employed as an easy-to-use standalone app, or from MATLAB or Python (both popular programming languages for earth scientists) and runs on MacOS, Linux or Windows 10. It is useful for research and teaching.

As well as making new interfaces to MELTS models, we also worked on expanding the underlying models so they can be applied more widely. Of particular interest is the fate of carbon in the earth’s mantle. Part of this effort involved setting up the LEPR+ (traceds.caltech.edu) database, updating it and adding more results from experiments where CO2 was added to the rock sample. We also uploaded experiments where the mineral amphibole (which is important in magma chamber processes) was observed. Within the alphaMELTS software, we added mineral phases of interest to the study of meteorites, and to planetary sciences, and adapted alphaMELTS for MATLAB/Python for modeling magmatism on the moon and Mars. As part of this award, we ran two workshops introducing users to alphaMELTS 2, and provided support for all MELTS software via the MAGMA website (magmasource.caltech.edu).
